title: Rotational KE - small cylinder on thin disc

content.question: A thin, uniform, circular disk of mass <math alttext="m sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and radius <math alttext="2 r sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> rotates at a constant angular velocity about a vertical axis through its center, as shown in the figure. On the top of the disk is a small dense cylinder of the same mass <math alttext="m sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. The cylinder moves in a circle of radius <math alttext="r sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> without slipping as the disk rotates. If the diameter of the cylinder is much smaller than <math alttext="r sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, which of the following statements is true?

choices.label: The thin disk has more kinetic energy than the small cylinder.
The small cylinder has more kinetic energy than the thin disk.
The kinetic energy is the same for the two objects.
The kinetic energies of the objects cannot be compared, since the thin disk has rotational kinetic energy and the small cylinder has translational kinetic energy.

content.answer: The thin disk has more kinetic energy than the small cylinder.
